Also, ordered the personal size pizza, "The Lou", which was amazing!  The pizza had spinach, garlic, and cheese.  It was the size of a personal pan pizza from PIZZA HUT!!  It definitely brought back my old high school days.  The pizza was so small that it made the $9.25 price "highway robbery"!  Actually it might be 1- 1/2 inch(es) smaller.  Remember how that personal pan pizza at PIZZA HUT was equivalent to one slice of pizza back in the day???  Anyway,  needless to say, the one pie wasn't filling enough so I ordered 2nd one (cheese).  Price wise it was equivalent to ordering a larger pie with more slices .  I have to say the sauce was just right.  It was super cheesy (quality cheese) and the butter crust was melt in your mouth not too hard,  just the right amount of crispiness!!  Verdict: really good pizza but spent way too much ($20.00 on 2 slices of pizza basically).

9.description: If you didn't get deep dish pizza, did you even go to Chicago? I'm a fan of both main chains that locals fight over for the acclaimed "locals' favorite" title when ur comes to deep dish. This experience at Lou Malnati's took the cake for me! First off, service and friendliness is of great value for me when dining. Being my third time in Chicago this visit, I really wanted to show my friends a great impression of Chicago. The kind spirited, friendly, and spirited waiter won them over as he joked around and made our dining experience so much fun. Definitely big points on that. We ordered a large "the Lou" and it was so perfect. Service-wise not only did our waiter inform us of all the possibilities for alternative ingredients for my food allergy (traded mixed spinach which had onions in it to fresh spinach which did not have onions), but also he gave basically a show for us as he cut the pizza and served us. The Lou is excellent and gives you great tastes of veggies. Man writing about it now even makes me want to go back to Chicago just for more Lou Malnati's. We left so satiated and happy from our first meal of our Chicago trip. Definitely will show all of my friends Lou's!

26.description: Great pizza restaurant near my hotel Essexs :)The mood is good and price also good.I can enjoy the restaurant even by myself. Of course good to come with family or friends.They have so many choice of sizes and toppings.I would like to order large size of deep dish pizza next time :)

25.description: All that hype.. I was at the peak of it. You what comes after the peak, the fall. I took my friend from Toronto to deliver the authentic Chicago Experience. What is more quintessential Chicago thing than the mighty Deep Dish Pizza? I have been to other popular chains, hence curious me, picked this place. We were greeted and seated right away. The interior is a standard Italian restaurant format cozy and welcoming. We ordered Medium sized The Malnati Chicago Classic with green peppers and olives. The waitress warned us that it would take half an hour for the pizza. So at least there upfront and clear about it. The pizza looked good. The crust was nicely browned and the contrasting Parmigiano-Reggiano on the tomato sauce was a nice touch. When the waitress placed a slice/piece, it was intact. The Pizza tasted good. Chewy mozzarella was just melted right amount and buttery crust was may be too crusty. The pizza sauce was well, I would say not the best I have had. The Italian sausage was not spicy, but I wish it was bit more spicy. Overall the Pizza was good. Oh I'm giving Three stars because of the aftermath. I think I got food poisoned that night. Prime suspect is the pizza. However I'm not leaving other food I had that day. I would visit another location of this chain to write another review.

12.description: I'm probably going to get crucified by LMP fans but this review was for the pizza ordered to-go and eaten in the hotel room as well as the frozen pizza I bought and flew back home to SoCal. Maybe we didn't cook it right, maybe..First of all, the ladies over the counter were rude and unfriendly. I was willing to overlook that if the pizza was mind blowingly good. Sad to say, it wasn't. The crust was thin and crisp, yes. There was lots of gooey mozzarella cheese topped with loads of sausage and tomatoes but somehow, it's missing a "wow" factor. I thought it was just me but everyone I ate it with echo my sentiments. It could've been over hyped is what it is which made our expectations soaring high. It's too bad though.To be fair, I probably should have dined in but I'm partly relieved I didn't because there are just too many good places to eat in Chicago and if I had the same outcome as when I ate it at the hotel and at home, I'd be bummed out to miss out on a better restaurant in this city.Perhaps when I'm in town again I'll give it another shot. Until then, 3 stars is all I could muster.

59.description: My first official real Chicago deep dish pizza. I don't really have anything to compare it to in that sense, but it was really good!

21.description: I had a Layover before going to Mexico. Now I was extremely unlucky with the weather and decided to get a Deepfry Pizza. I had read on Yelp's Chatboard about good places to go and Lou Malnati's seems like a food chain with great reviews for their deepfry pizza It's my first time trying the real thing. I did like 1 hours transit from the airport to the restaurant with like 15 minutes of being soaking wet by this wet-snow in this windy weather. So Chicago is nice, the place looks good but my only super positive moment that day was eating that pizza. Made me feel like the struggle was worth it. I'll be honest, I'm not a huge fan of that type of pizza but I get the appeal and felt it had a almost healthy feel to it. The service was impeccable and my waitress was very nice. I will go back to Chicago in better circumstance for a longer period of time and I'm sure that when I'll go back to get a Deepfry pizza this will not be the only amazing moment of my stay there!

17.description: Chicago deep dish pizza... Always a must when you come into town... but never a stunner. Let's be honest with each other and set out all the facts beforehand -- I'm a NY pizza lover, so Chicago pizza does not tickle my fancy. The pizza itself is massive. Unless you have a huge appetite or really love heavy pizza, two slices will be your max --  the waitress may try to tell you otherwise, but either you'll be full by then or sick of eating the same ol' thing. We ordered the sausage pizza -- which was heavily loaded with cheese. A fork and knife in hand, I attacked the pizza. Thank goodness for that, because the crust is not crispy.Overall, impressive? Prob not. But would I do it again, most likely because no trip to Chicago is complete without a slice of deep dish pizza.

I liked that we could order some stuff ahead of time and grab drinks while waiting. It took some time to be seated, but they were able to accommodate us.For food, we had The Lou for our pizza with mushrooms and olives added and the Chicken Louie. I don't know how this compares to the other pizzerias, but our party was very satisfied with our food.

Prime suspect is the pizza. However I'm not leaving other food I had that day. I would visit another location of this chain to write another review.

35.description: Chicago classic pizza is delicious, I'm correcting an earlier review, as they have more than made up for it in my most recent experience. The butter crust is impossible to beat, best pizza in the city.

19.description: There are tons of places to get a decent Chicago style deep dish pizza. I practically tried about 5 difference places during my short trip. Lou Malnati's, well you are franchised as hell and all over the place, but you are still a winner. Lou Malnati's won me for best buttery crust.I ended up stopping by this location during a trip around the Loop and walking around the snowy park. It was the lunch hour and this place was relatively packed. Lou Malnati's at this location took over 2 side by side restaurant spaces, so even while busy, there was ample space with minimal wait.-=-Lunch Deep Dish-=- Best way to eat deep dish is to not stuff yourself crazy, like most portions end up being. The lunch portion deep dish, perfecto. The sauce is sweet, but not over overly bearing. The best part though was the crust. It was flaky with a buttery crunch. It didn't quite excel in the cheesiness category, but you really can't have it all. A+, I will crave this again.

28.description: Conveniently located near the Hilton hotel. Personal deep dish pizza is really small. I would recommend getting salad and/or appetizers if you're hungry. The service is a bit slow but the staff is friendly.

45.description: We usually frequent the buffalo Grove locations bc I lost hope for the downtown locations. My fiance loves pizza, we were in the city that day. We stopped in, usually and always I order easy on the cheese and more sauce. I'm lactose in tolerant. Waitress never heard of that kind of order. I asked her to ask the manager and she said I've been here forever and never heard such a way. Let me ask if the cooks know how to make it. 15 mins later she came back saying it wasn't possible. So I had the crust of a slice of pizza and My fiance tried to enjoy his pizza without feeling bad. Thanks for ruining pizza service LM downtown again.  It sucks to have to pay for parking, pay for food and service that all blows.

33.description: We had high expectations, ordered thin crust with spinach and tomatoes and deep dish with sausage meet, as announced the deep dish pizza took 40 min to be ready, unfortunately when served both pizzas were barely warm, had to send them back. re-heating the pizzas made a positive difference. We had the house salad family size, very fresh and huge. Too bad the Pizzas were forgotten en-route.

43.description: Lou Malnati's is at the top of my list when getting pizza in Chicago. Be prepared to wait: we had to order, then wait 30 minutes for a table. Once we were seated, our server was friendly and attentive. She was more than happy to change something with our order even when it was (probably) too late to expect it. The garlic bread is amazing and served with marinara for dipping. Then there's the pizza. This is true deep dish at its best. The crust is excellent and can be snapped with a fork (you MUST knife and fork it). Though they say a large feeds four, I think a medium would be plenty. (I'm an eater and was full after one slice). Note: if you love Lou's, you can take home a pie or two and relive the experience in your own oven.

2.description: The locals all recommend this place. Did not disappoint. Service was friendly and welcoming when we got in. Ordered the Malnati's pizza,  it easy a tasty pizza. Large pieces of sausage and full of flavor. I only wished they had more sauce to top the pizza. I am a heavy sauce person, it's a mall subjective. Butter crust was good also. Great spot to try a malls ND rat for my first time Chicago pizza.

18.description: The first thing we did when we landed and got settled in the hotel Hyatt at Mccormick place was order food. Thank God ! Lou Malnati's delivered because I didn't know there wasn't around the Mccormick!...I mean nothing! We ordered our first authentic Chicago deep dish and some cheddar bites. The pizza was tasty but really heavy. It made me so sleepy that I didn't want to go sight seeing....but my husband dragged me out of the room. lol The cheese bites had a great crunch to it and the cheddar had a bite to it. It was little too salty for me though. The pizza and the bites both had very generous servings . If you just want to eat and chill out in the room watching a little TV Lou Malnati's is perfect!

41.description: This is hands-down my favorite pizza in Chicago, deep-dish of course.  (I think thin crust is for amateurs!)It's just something about the crust having the right amount of flakiness and buttery taste that no other pizza establishment has been able to compete with.  When it comes to freshness, you just can't beat this pie.I've tried the rest.  And for me, this is definitely the best.

52.description: Lou Malnati's is home of my favorite pizza worldwide. I've never once been disappointed. The fact that they let you pre-order your pizza while you wait to be seated is awesome too, so it's less waiting once you're seated (because they tell you deep dish takes 45 minutes to cook). Get the Malnati salad as a starter! The dressing, a sweet vinaigrette, is incredible. I've never tasted a dressing like it elsewhere (need to buy a bottle of it one of these days). Expect to wait if you come during a busy time, but any wait is worth it for this deep dish.

50.description: Another item crossed off my Chicago bucket list! Having a real deep dish pizza. Yum. And Lou Malnati does it good. For appetizers, we ordered the Trio of Dips and Pizza Chips (not crunchy), it was a good starter if you like carbs. My personal favorite was the artichoke dip. This is a huge appetizer so it's good for sharing, but if you're hungry like we were, it might only be enough for two. For the pizza (they warn you it takes about 30 minutes to bake), we got The Malnati Chicago Classic™. "Made with Lou's lean sausage, some extra cheese and vine-ripened tomato sauce on Buttercrust.™ It's authentic Chicago!". The buttercrust is delicious! If you get a different pizza, be sure to upgrade to this crust, it's awesome. The sausage is wonderful, it compliments the pizza so well and they make sure to put plenty of it in the pizza. We got the small size which is recommended to serve 2 people. At first you might look at it and think it's not enough but once you're finished, you'll realize, it was the perfect size.   During our visit, we had this place, TWICE! It was that good. We're not even going to bother trying another place.

4.description: It's probably not fair of me to even review this place, as I am not a deep-dish fan, but... still gonna. As far as deep dish goes, I suppose I haven't had better. We got the Lou with pepperoni added. Ingredients seemed fresh. Sauce was good. It was too cheezy for my tastes, but that's probably the nature of deep dish. Deep dish is probably why pizza is also called "pie." It's very pie-like indeed, with a thick crust and very heavy/rich contents. Even for non-deep-dish fans, I'd say it's worth a try; after all, you are in Chicago. The wait wasn't too bad. They told us about 20-25 minutes but I think it ended up being probably less than 10. We started on a couple of really good beers while we waited for a table. Matilda (Beligan style) and The Poet (a porter by a Michigan Brewery).

6.description: When in Chicago, you gotta have the deep dish pizza.  And if you're only in town for five days, you gotta trust your Yelpers to find the best place in town, and that brought me to Lou Malnati's.  I came here on a Saturday night, and it was packed, as expected.  You're cozied up to all the other parties waiting for their tables as well, and the delicious aromas of pizza and warmth permeate your senses and definitely works up your appetite.  We waited about 45 minutes for a table of five.  You can order your food when you're still in line so that by the time you sit down, they'll fully bake the pizza and it'll come out quicker.  Very efficient in my opinion.We ordered the combination platter since we couldn't just choose one appetizer.  This came with mozzarella sticks, cheddar cubes, breaded mushrooms and zucchini.  They were all good, but just a lot of fried food so don't fill up on appetizers too quickly.  We ordered a large The Malnati Chicago Classic pizza and it was to die for.  It was as good as I thought it would be.  The servers were super friendly and accommodating too, which made the experience even better.  They bring the pizza out on a tray to your table and they serve you individually.  Since it's deep dish, it's a lot more filling than you would expect, so I had about two slices, but we had some leftovers.  When I am in Chicago next, I will definitely be back!

22.description: If you didn't get deep dish pizza, did you even go to Chicago? I'm a fan of both main chains that locals fight over for the acclaimed "locals' favorite" title when ur comes to deep dish. This experience at Lou Malnati's took the cake for me! First off, service and friendliness is of great value for me when dining. Being my third time in Chicago this visit, I really wanted to show my friends a great impression of Chicago. The kind spirited, friendly, and spirited waiter won them over as he joked around and made our dining experience so much fun. Definitely big points on that. We ordered a large "the Lou" and it was so perfect. Service-wise not only did our waiter inform us of all the possibilities for alternative ingredients for my food allergy (traded mixed spinach which had onions in it to fresh spinach which did not have onions), but also he gave basically a show for us as he cut the pizza and served us. The Lou is excellent and gives you great tastes of veggies. Man writing about it now even makes me want to go back to Chicago just for more Lou Malnati's. We left so satiated and happy from our first meal of our Chicago trip. Definitely will show all of my friends Lou's!

15.description: This was GREAT pizza! Deep Dish, Chicago, Buttered Crust pizza! These folks have an efficient process for getting you in and out. Don't be discouraged if it is busy and their is a wait. They put your name on the list, give you a wait time and encourage you to pre-order at the counter before being seated, so that your food is practically ready when you sit down. GENIUS! The staff was great! very friendly and accommodating!

57.description: I enjoyed the crust but didn't like the large tomatoes chunks in the sauce. This pizza also didn't hold up for next day eating...

20.description: First time trying original Chicago deep dish and I was not disappointed! The crust and cheese were so delicious and we also got the bruschetta, which for the type of place this is, couldn't be beat. I'll definitely be back next time I'm in the Windy City!

36.description: I had to get an obligatory Lou's review along with the rest of my pizza reviews. I probably get a deep dish from this location at least twice a month. Although everyone has their favorite deep dish pizza in Chicago (mine being Pequod's) this has to be one of the top recognized names along with Gino's and Giordano's. Lou's has a crispy crust, ample amount of cheese, and a large tomato chunk style sauce. I really wouldn't even consider it much of a "sauce", but more of a topping. Needless to say, there really isn't anything out there like it. One slice and you are full. The sausage also comes slab style across the entire pizza. I personally request and prefer their sausage pieces instead. Also, be sure to order the butter crust. It adds a great flavor! Other lesser known option that is nice is the lower-fat mozzarella cheese. I really could not tell the difference. As another "healthier" option, they now serve poultry sausage, which is also delicious. Taste a piece of Chicago history, stop by Lou's, and get a deep dish pizza!

14.description: Sorry, Lou, but I just don't get the hype.  When visiting Chicago, I always make it a point to get deep dish pizza at least once.  On my last two trips, I tried Gino's East and Pizzeria Due (Uno's sibling), so I figured this time, I'd give Lou's a shot.  Since I was there in connection with a large convention, I figured the wait would be at least an hour, and was prepared to settle for take out.  However, I was quoted a wait time of 35 min., so I decided to wait for a table.  The quote was exactly right, and I put in my pizza order ahead of time to expedite things.I decided to try the Lou's salad for an appetizer ($9.25), which consists of romaine lettuce, Roma tomatoes, black olives, mushrooms, salami bits, and romano cheese drizzled with Lou's signature sweet balsamic vinaigrette.  This salad is quite generously portioned, despite being an individual size, and I wasn't able to finish it, since I needed to save stomach real estate for the pizza.  Despite that, it was quite good, and turned out to be the highlight of the meal.For my pizza, I ordered a small Lou ($16.30), which consists of spinach, mushrooms, and sliced Roma tomatoes in addition to the usual ingredients of crust, cheese, and tomato sauce.  Given that the small is designed to serve two people, I decided to order it rather than the individual size because I wanted to take leftovers back to my hotel to eat for lunch the next day.  While I will say that the butter crust is notable, and is superior to the crusts of other deep dish pies I've tried in Chi-town, I was less than impressed with the flavors of the other components of the pie, which didn't have the depth and marriage of other deep dish pies I've tried.  Like all deep dish pies, Lou's pie is quite substantial, so expect it to sit on your stomach like a brick, and plan accordingly (I forgot this the next day and regretted it).For dessert, I had the individual sized classic deep dish cookie a la mode ($3.50), which I'd eyed but never tried at other deep dish pizzerias.  While the temperature contrast was nice, again, I found the flavors lacking in depth, and the size was smaller than I'd envisioned.  I should have either ordered the regular portion or something else, such as the brownie sundae.Overall, while my meal at Lou's was certainly filling, it didn't quite meet the standards I was expecting in terms of flavor, particularly given that it's the best rated of the major deep dish chains in Chicago.  While I'm glad that I tried it, next time, I think I'll try a different deep dish pizzeria that I haven't tried yet, such as Giordano's or Pequod's, which seems to be a local favorite.  3.5 stars.

58.description: Wonderful, classy sushi place in the South Loop. Went here on a first date and keep going back for date night regularly. It's easy to get a seat if your party is two people, but definitely make a reservation if you have three or more - I had to wait over an hour to be seated with three people once. The waiters make great suggestions on which specialty rolls to try - the Mexicana and Chicago rolls are delicious. I always get warm sake and miso soup with my meals. I recently tried the seaweed salad, and it was a great appetizer as well. The atmosphere inside is very lovely, not too loud, and intimate.

56.description: This restaurant may not be good for sushi (from other guys reviews, I haven't tried) but if you want to have other Japanese foods with a reasonable price, this restaurant would be a good choice. I like their Katsu Kare and ramen.

29.description: Ordered:    -Miso Ramen = Delicious   -Green Tea = On Point    -California Maki Roll = Good just a little too salty :/   -Lychee Sorbet = Good Overall I loved the food and you're given water free lol One star taken away because waitress wasn't the greatest, not very kind.

42.description: I eat at Umai at least once a month. I would highly recommend the Katsu Don and Nabeyaki. Entrees are served in very large portions for a decent price. Great atmosphere. Quick preparation if you are needing take out. +10% discount for online orders!

23.description: Any sushi restaurant that has Hitachino White Ale is top notch in my book. You can't find that stuff everywhere!We ate everything. We drank beer and sake. I can't remember anything we ate that wasn't delicious. I would return in a heartbeat and would recommend this place to anyone.

47.description: I only ordered out...I want to eat in next time.Food - My wife and I got the Sloopin, Mexicana, and the Philly roll. It was delicious, the fish tasted fresh and the combo of flavors made every bite worth every penny. Every sushi bite stuck together and never fell apart which is a huge plus.Service - Host was extremely friendly and food was ready fast. Everyone seemed to want to help. I will judge eat in service next time, but it seems people generally feel the same way.Atmosphere - Nothing out of the ordinary and kind of in step with any other higher class sushi bar. Regardless, I still felt a desire to want to eat in.Food - 2/2Service - 2/2Atmosphere - 1/1

8.description: I got to stop in here for lunch while I was in the neighborhood, and luckily there was no long wait though the restaurant was full! Right when you walk in, the amazing smell greets you, which you know is a good sign for things to come.I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and my SO got the spicy garlic pork ramen-- wow wow wow! The broth in both our our ramens was very intensely rich and had a sort of smoky flavor, which I had never had before. The chashu was grilled and very tender, and the rest of the toppings were on point- a nice serving of seaweek and corn in mine, which I loved. I of course had to steal a bite of the spicy garlic pork ramen, which was super flavorful. Full warning- they do not skimp on the garlic, and you will stink for the rest of the day... but I'd say it's worth it! The only thing I'm taking a star off for is the service- we did have to stand around and wait for a hostess to notice us, even though several waiters passed us by on their way out of the kitchen. It also took a long time for our check to come, even though we were one of only a few tables by the time we were done. Slow service aside, though, this place is great!

31.description: Nice place, amazing food!!! Japanese food the way I like it!!!

34.description: Great place to have a drink and have some sushi. The ramen was good but nothing out of the ordinary. Would go back to try out the different ramen they have.

16.description: Any sushi restaurant that has Hitachino White Ale is top notch in my book. You can't find that stuff everywhere!We ate everything. We drank beer and sake. I can't remember anything we ate that wasn't delicious. I would return in a heartbeat and would recommend this place to anyone.

13.description: We had a great dinner tonight at Umai. The sushi was delicious, with very reasonable prices for specialty rolls the portions were awesome! We couldn't help but look at the ramen dishes others around us ordered so we will be back to try that next time!

11.description: i've been here a few times with larger groups after having classes at Equilibrium and they've been pretty accommodating on short notice with no reservation, when it was a weekend. The menu is comprehensive when it comes to representing Japanese food: they have several different kinds of ramens, a wide selection of sushi, and entrees to boot. I have only tried their ramen & udon - once the nabeyaki udon (which is great when you have no idea what you want but you want soup), and the ramen dipping noodle (which is a bit confusing in terms of how to eat but it is delicious). Prices are a little on the fancy side and service is fine. The nice this also is that they are OK with providing separate checks if you ask them when you sit down for a larger group (6-12 people) so that's really nice too. I'll definitely be back here when I'm in the South Loop and want some Japanese food.

39.description: Had the dipping noodles, sushi roll and saki.  Solid!  I'd be back to try more.  and more and more...  Service was really good and I like the ambiance.

37.description: Love the spicy pork ramen (get extra spicy pork for $2 extra- well worth it for the homemade goodness). Sushi is solid, appetized done on the japanese grill were fantastic. But I have come back just for that spicy pork ramen on a cool winter night twice already, since discovering it a month ago.

0.description: I've been here twice and both times had a good experience. It's a great restaurant to go to if you're watching a movie at Showplace Icon and looking for a place to eat since there aren't many food options near the theater. The first time I went there, I ordered the Katsu Kare. The portion was huge; I could only finish half of it. Hardly any of the Japanese restaurants I've been to serve Katsu Kare so I was pleasantly surprised to see it on the menu. I thought the curry had good flavor. It's definitely a comfort dish.Most recently, I ordered the Spicy Roasted Garlic Pork Ramen - spicy miso ground pork, wakame seaweed, fish cake, half boiled egg, Japanese leeks, braised pork belly and garlic chips. The broth had great flavor and the pork was cooked perfectly. I highly recommend it for people that love ramen. Overall, Umai has great food. It's a good option if you're in the area and craving Japanese food.

38.description: We were craving some ramen and sushi and found this gem on Yelp. The food was definitely delicious, and fish portions were great- nice and thick. Service was not the best though. Our waitress took a while getting our orders, and this was when the restaurant was pretty empty also. Nonetheless, we were very satisfied with our food:Chicago roll: a crowd favorite! We had about 3 orders of this roll- delicious with good portions of fresh tasting fish with nice additional flavors in the sauce.Mexicana roll: this was also good, I'm just not a big fan of jalapeño in my sushi. But it was a nice refreshing roll otherwise.Overall, food was excellent and the restaurant atmosphere was great, with good smells of ramen and sushi. Besides the slow service, we had a great experience!

51.description: Great atmosphere, great food.  There's a reason this place is busy every day of the week!  Nigiri is fresh and generous in portions. Udon and noodles are very tasty.  Most importantly, wifey loves it so I can always bring her on a winning date and look awesome. Everyone I know loves it, I love it.  Share the love.

27.description: I came here with a colleague who studied abroad in Japan and we both really enjoyed our meal. I ordered salmon sashimi on sushi rice and the spicy roasted garlic pork ramen while my colleague ordered the soba noodles. The salmon tasted super fresh and the ramen was very spicy/flavorful. There was so much food, I could barely finish my meal.

32.description: Umai was a nice spot to dine on Saturday night! Pretty on point with most of the dishes - not too big or too small for the price. We did edamame, skewers of beef tongue and steak, fried chicken wings, sushi rolls, and sukiyaki. All tasty and served quick. This along with a few Kirins and it was a good night.

54.description: Sushi rolls are delicious and fresh. Ramen is a nice serving size but spicy one didn't have much flavor.

48.description: We had a great meal at Umai. We started with sushi. It was very fresh and flavorful. For my main dish, I ordered a bowl of udon noodles and loved it.

44.description: Slightly above average. Hamachi collar was good and so was the lunch salmon teriyaki. Lunch chirasi for $18 has only about 9 thinly sliced pieces of fish on top of the sushi rice. which is less in quantity and higher priced than other places that I have been to. Service was good so bumped from 3.5 to 4 stars.

24.description: Love this place. I live a block away, so we get carry-out frequently. The sushi and ramen dishes are delicious. You can't go wrong here.

7.description: Ate here with a friend, as I recently moved in down the street.  The food isn't bad (as stated by others, a bit steep for the neighborhood though) and they have great service.  Everything that we both ordered was good, fresh, and the Ramen was good also. Also has a fun atmosphere.

49.description: Good sushi, sub par ramen.  Also, there were flies at the sushi bar which left something to be desired.  go elsewhere if you can.

40.description: Ate here with a friend, as I recently moved in down the street.  The food isn't bad (as stated by others, a bit steep for the neighborhood though) and they have great service.  Everything that we both ordered was good, fresh, and the Ramen was good also. Also has a fun atmosphere.

53.description: excellent sushi very good service and a relatively quiet environment despite being very busy

30.description: Fabulous restaurant...everyone was nice, efficient and helpful.   The food was great! I recommend it.

46.description: If you're looking for a good Japanese restaurant in the South Loop, Umai is THE Place! Ate at Umai twice in 1 week (lunch and for dinner) and both times had exceeded my expectations.  Good service, great ambience, easy parking, and of course... good quality food! They have Lunch sets ($10 - $15) & is enough food to put you into a food coma!Their soup noodles are all really good - Beef Sukiyaki, Tempura Udon & Pork belly Ramen are all a must try! The nigiri are very fresh and they are large cut, draping over the rice.The grill selection is not many, but the Beef tongue & Pork shoulders are very tasty.Will definitely come back!

1.description: Compared to sushi places in SF, Umai was average but good enough to satisfy your sushi craving. Our hotel was on S Michigan Ave, right across the street from Grant Park, so Umai was within a nice walking distance. We walked in on a Thursday night and didn't have to wait to get a seat.I ordered the 10 pc omakase, and the boyfriend ordered a couple rolls. I think he had the White Tuna Jalapeno roll, Chicago roll and a hamachi roll. The fish was fresh and well-presented, but overall nothing super special.The decor was super nice. Umai is definitely trying to pull off a modern, upscale-ish, hipster-y atmosphere.If you're looking for some sushi while you're in the South Loop area, I would give this a try.

55.description: Ordered delivery 3 times and been here once.  Great food and worth the 1 hr wait for delivery.  Love their agedashi tofu, order it every time.  Really tender pieces of tofu, covered in a crispy yet chewy shell, plus great dipping sauce.  It's my favorite agedashi in Chicago.  Saving their dipping sauce and trying to replicate the tofu part at home, not sure if I can do it as well!

9.description: I came here with a colleague who studied abroad in Japan and we both really enjoyed our meal. I ordered salmon sashimi on sushi rice and the spicy roasted garlic pork ramen while my colleague ordered the soba noodles. The salmon tasted super fresh and the ramen was very spicy/flavorful. There was so much food, I could barely finish my meal.

26.description: My wife and I went here on our hunt to eat all the ramen Chicago has to offer. Umai was a great way to continue our journey. I went with the spicy garlic ramen and it was awesome! Not mega hot but had some great smokey heat to it. Their grilled pork was tender and delicious. The noodles were a little thinner than I'm used to, but still really good and chewy. Their sushi was awesome too. We only split a roll for an appetizer but seeing other tables made me want to come back to try more.

25.description: I got the Winter Ramen and the veggie gyoza via delivery (until midnight!), and this meal has me choked up with happiness. I've had ramen from 5 or 6 places in Chicago, and this was the best (and this was delivery!). The broth was tasty and ever so slightly spicy. The poached egg in the ramen was perfectly cooked. The veggie gyoza are weird. They almost taste like they have pesto in them. Still, definitely the good kind of weird.

12.description: Stopped by on a chilly day - which meant I was trying to decide between sushi (my original plan) and ramen. I ended up getting both -- a spicy tuna roll ($7) and the garlic pork spicy miso ramen ($14). The spicy tuna came in 8 pieces -- the tuna wasn't chopped tiny and there was no mayo, so +1. As for the ramen, the noodle texture were more like egg noodles (full disclosure: my guideline for ramen is Santouka). As other reviewers have noted, the spicy miso is not all that spicy (more like a layer on top of a miso) -- and the broth is not very porky, but on the plus, there were plenty of scallions and the egg was done perfectly. As for the meat, I think I would have preferred more of the spicy ground pork and less of the belly, which definitely felt out of place (probably placed in last?) and not as tender as I would have liked.My friend had a chirashi -- at $25, it was quite large -- the size of my ramen bowl -- and she had trouble finishing it. There was a good variety of fish (eyeballing it, probably 8 or 9 kinds with 2 to 3 pieces each?) and the salmon in particular looked quite fresh.The garlic pork ramen is good for folks who like lighter broths, and it hit the spot for that particularly cold day. That said, I think I would probably get a couple of rolls next time. This is a pretty good option for South Loop.

59.description: The atmosphere and services were nice and relaxing. But the food on the other hand was not so great. We ordered the spicy  garlic pork ramen and the broth was so SALTY; and the noodle was hard. We also ordered half the le bonki and half of Chicago roll. The salmon on the le bonki was not fresh. The only decent dish we ordered was the Chicago roll.

21.description: I'm not a sushi fan...I took my boyfriend here as a surprise to him. He enjoyed himself immensely. He said the Ramen was great and the different types of sushi he tried was good. His favorite sushi was the mexicana. He did say they were a little pricey. But the great service was worth it. For someone who doesn't eat sushi there was a few choices. I had the hanger steak and that was pretty good. So over all great service and food. My only small complaint was the drink I had...I had a chocolate martini and it wasn't that good at all. Not horrible, just didn't taste like a chocolate martini should.

17.description: Umai is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in Chicago. There are always plenty of Japanese dishes to choose from and the fish is always fresh. Furthermore, the vegetarian sushi options make it very easy to arrange dinners with friends who may not enjoy Japanese food otherwise.The best ramen I have had so far in Chicago, I have found at Umai. The soup base and noodle texture are on par with the Ippudo chain of restaurants, a personal favorite of mine when I visit the likes of Taipei and New York. The Nabeyaki Udon is also a delicious alternative during the winter time.The sushi and sashimi is always fresh. I enjoy anything from the spicy tuna, made with honey sriracha to the ama ebi, classically served with the shrimp heads.Umai is always a great place to stop in the South Loop and I always look forward to returning.

10.description: Umai was a nice spot to dine on Saturday night! Pretty on point with most of the dishes - not too big or too small for the price. We did edamame, skewers of beef tongue and steak, fried chicken wings, sushi rolls, and sukiyaki. All tasty and served quick. This along with a few Kirins and it was a good night.

5.description: Umai is my "now, where was that place" place. I've been here enough times that it really shouldn't be in my restaurant blind spot but I think that after last night, I've finally got it locked on my mental map - (Blue line LaSalle, walk to Polk) - though the exterior looks totally different without the summertime patio. (Quite possibly the noisiest, horn-honkiest intersection on which a patio sits, by the way.)Ramen!! It's delicious. I've tried several and so far, "winter ramen" tops my list ($14.00) It's "medium" spice but they can dial it upon request.  The broth is well-layered and the beef, so tender. Sushi I've had here has always been fresh and service has been easily five stars. (I've had same server three times over five months, inside/outside! and he is always smiling.)I find the prices slightly steep for the location though and also, there's no happy hour. I think it's ok to mention that a fun neighborhood bar "First Draft" opened not too long ago across Clark and "Sociale" just went in across Polk, so this area is definitely growing. When you want ramen though, you want ramen! I'm definitely locked on Umai.

3.description: This place was fantastic and had it all. It's a hip and trendy restaurant that is great for date night because you can dress down or up and fit in. The service is wonderful as well. They have a gray cocktail selection. I had the lychee martinis and it was delightful. Not too sweet and it brings actual lychee to be able to eat!The beef hangar appetizer was my favorite!!! It was so tender and it had a great sweet sauce on it. The sashimi was very fresh. I tried the tuna and salmon. My friend and I shared several rolls and sadly I can't remember the names but they were all so good!! My friend had their creams brûlée. The initialBite was different, interesting. But as she continued to eat she really grew to appreciate the dessert and love it. The only dish that didn't taste like all the flavors went together was their salmon carpaccio.

35.description: Love their food and service! Ask for their fatty salmon that they carry occasionally. It's super good. They can even make that into a spicy salmon roll. It is the best spicy salmon I've ever got! Beef tongues are good too.

19.description: Yummmmmm! I love this place. Had the best variety of Japanese food I've seen, more than just sushi and chicken teriyaki. The katsu don is the best I've ever had in the US, and I love many of their dishes. Their sushi is not the best for me, but I'll admit, it could be because they are dressed minimally like you would find in Japan and not slathered in sauces and crunchy things (which I do love.) But at the same time, I do appreciate minimally dressed sushi and this still doesn't do much for me. Green tea creme brûlée is amazing though!! Wish they had some more dishes I love like yakisoba, but that's more of a street food, I guess and can't hold that against them. It gets REALLY BUSY here, so most of the time I get my food to go.

28.description: Umai is great.  The ramen is delicious and comparable to Wasabi or other solid ramen places around the city.  Sushi is hit or miss with more swooshes than air balls. Ambiance is decent and service is great.  Not byob.  Small/mid size, clean, and modern restaurant. No TVs in eating area. Good place for a date. Parking is a little tough in that area and this place can be packed on weekends.  Make sure you get a reservation.  This place is better than most in nearby Chinatown.  I definitely recommend.

45.description: Stopped by on a chilly day - which meant I was trying to decide between sushi (my original plan) and ramen. I ended up getting both -- a spicy tuna roll ($7) and the garlic pork spicy miso ramen ($14). The spicy tuna came in 8 pieces -- the tuna wasn't chopped tiny and there was no mayo, so +1. As for the ramen, the noodle texture were more like egg noodles (full disclosure: my guideline for ramen is Santouka). As other reviewers have noted, the spicy miso is not all that spicy (more like a layer on top of a miso) -- and the broth is not very porky, but on the plus, there were plenty of scallions and the egg was done perfectly. As for the meat, I think I would have preferred more of the spicy ground pork and less of the belly, which definitely felt out of place (probably placed in last?) and not as tender as I would have liked.My friend had a chirashi -- at $25, it was quite large -- the size of my ramen bowl -- and she had trouble finishing it. There was a good variety of fish (eyeballing it, probably 8 or 9 kinds with 2 to 3 pieces each?) and the salmon in particular looked quite fresh.The garlic pork ramen is good for folks who like lighter broths, and it hit the spot for that particularly cold day. That said, I think I would probably get a couple of rolls next time. This is a pretty good option for South Loop.

33.description: This place was good! Service was friendly, sushi was yummy and fresh. The grilled cauliflower was lacking in flavor and they poured their beers with tons of foam, but my lychee martini was perfect, as was all my nigiri! If you need a sushi fix, this spot is a solid option.

43.description: I eat here literally once a week. Being an Amli resident this place is not only convenient but tasty as well. Menu ranges from steaks to great ramen & of course sushi.

2.description: A few moments stood out to me last night as my husband and I went out on a double date with another couple:Pros: food was good! Lots of options. Very trendy place. Cons: -husband and I got there before the other couple. Asked if there was a reservation under their two last names. The woman checked and said no. And then we asked how long the wait would be, and she said "probably an hour to an hour and a half. You should have made a reservation, sorry!"  Then my friend gets there and says she DID make a reservation. Gives the woman the same name I told her. The woman apologizes and takes us immediately to our table. -I and the two husbands ordered beer. The waitress poured my beer into a glass and handed it to me. She then asked each man individually if they wanted their beer in a glass. So, do women not get to make this choice? Just a tiny bit of sexism to start off the meal. -the sushi wasn't timed right with the rest of the meal, as the two men ordered sushi. We got our food about 10 minutes before one husband, and my husband got his food a good 8 minutes after that. -I ordered spicy ramen soup. The waitress asked me "medium spice?" And I said, well I like spicy things. Can I go for spicier? She said that she recommended a 2-3 out of 5, but she'd bring me spicy powder for my soup. The soup was basically not spicy at all, which was annoying to me, since I ordered it and mentioned the spice as being important to me. Spicy powder wasn't even chili flakes or chili oil, so didn't help. -overall, food was fine, but I felt somewhat targeted as a white woman in this restaurant through tiny micro aggressions- though definitely unintentional, I didn't feel as valued as a customer.

18.description: Highly recommend the sukiyaki if you are looking for something warm and hearty and isn't sushi. Great menu overall - good balance of sushi, udon and ramen, don, tempura, katsu, and yakitori. Will be back next time I'm in Chicago.

41.description: Umai is my "now, where was that place" place. I've been here enough times that it really shouldn't be in my restaurant blind spot but I think that after last night, I've finally got it locked on my mental map - (Blue line LaSalle, walk to Polk) - though the exterior looks totally different without the summertime patio. (Quite possibly the noisiest, horn-honkiest intersection on which a patio sits, by the way.)Ramen!! It's delicious. I've tried several and so far, "winter ramen" tops my list ($14.00) It's "medium" spice but they can dial it upon request.  The broth is well-layered and the beef, so tender. Sushi I've had here has always been fresh and service has been easily five stars. (I've had same server three times over five months, inside/outside! and he is always smiling.)I find the prices slightly steep for the location though and also, there's no happy hour. I think it's ok to mention that a fun neighborhood bar "First Draft" opened not too long ago across Clark and "Sociale" just went in across Polk, so this area is definitely growing. When you want ramen though, you want ramen! I'm definitely locked on Umai.

52.description: My husband and I order from here often, and the food never disappoints.  Last night, we had the tempura platter as an appetizer, which is one of my favorites here.  Mixed vegetables and shrimp fried to perfection with a tasty dipping sauce.  We then ordered one of the evening specials: the king crab miso ramen.  It was fantastic!  We each ordered one but weren't able to finish it because the helping was so large.  In the past, we've also had a variety of their sushi offerings, which have always been terrific.  The price is reasonable, and the service is good.  The restaurant is always full with other patrons, but we've never had to wait long to be seated.  We will definitely be eating here again.

50.description: This was my first Japanese food experience and I loved it. I had the Udon Kare and Shrimp Tempura roll. Delicious! Fun atmosphere and kind servers.

4.description: We were craving some ramen and sushi and found this gem on Yelp. The food was definitely delicious, and fish portions were great- nice and thick. Service was not the best though. Our waitress took a while getting our orders, and this was when the restaurant was pretty empty also. Nonetheless, we were very satisfied with our food:Chicago roll: a crowd favorite! We had about 3 orders of this roll- delicious with good portions of fresh tasting fish with nice additional flavors in the sauce.Mexicana roll: this was also good, I'm just not a big fan of jalapeño in my sushi. But it was a nice refreshing roll otherwise.Overall, food was excellent and the restaurant atmosphere was great, with good smells of ramen and sushi. Besides the slow service, we had a great experience!

6.description: Will definitely be returning here again. The sushi was very fresh, we were served promptly, and the ramen was great. We stopped in at around 530-6pm and were seated right away. Was surprised at how quickly the restaurant filled up considering it was Superbowl Sunday. We ordered the highly recommended spicy roasted garlic pork ramen, a half Chicago roll, a spicy scallop hand roll, and hamachi nigiri. The sushi was just mmmmmm =) so good. The hand roll was HUGE. Super stuffed with the spicy scallop mixture, and was very well balanced with the sauce and masago. The hamachi was so soft, and the Chicago roll was not as memorable, but was a great try off their menu. I really, really wanted to order more nigiri, especially after tasting how fresh and soft the hamachi was. But the ramen was quite filling, and the Chicago rolls are large rolls, not your avg size. The waitress was kind enough to suggest that the kitchen split our ramen order into two bowls after learning we were planning on sharing it, but I regretted this decision. The bowls are quite small, and the noodle amount the same, so you get a lot less broth than if you were to receive it in the original bowl. Next time, I'd just ask for a side bowl, and deal with splitting it ourselves. Also, the ramen was amazingggg just wished it didn't have SO MUCH bamboo shoots. I love them, the SO does not, so I usually end up eating all of them myself... and it was just way way too much.All in all, loved this little place.Excited that they're opening up a second location in the Lincoln Park area! Hopefully both locations are on par with one another.

22.description: Love this spot! Great ramen & sushi in one spot. Menu is big and never disappoints. Prices are reasonable for dine in and carry out. My favorite is the spicy scallop hand roll or the super white with scallions. Delicious!

15.description: The Katsu Don was amazing along with the shrimp tempura roll! The Katsu Don comes with salad and miso soup too. The salad was amazing and same with the miso soup. Both small servings but the flavor was perfect! The dressing on the salad tasted like ginger and wasn't too overpowering. The Katsu Don had an amazing flavor! The serving was big so you definitely get what you pay for. The shrimp tempura roll was huge so the rolls are definitely worth it. The servers were great and the atmosphere was very nice.

57.description: Love the ramen!  I usually get the Ton Kotsu with extra Shashu.  I have tried a few rolls and some appetizers, all very good.  Just moved to South Loop from burbs where the two top ramen places are, but their ramen did not disappoint.  I will be a regular here for sure.  Atmosphere is very nice. UPDATE:  I have been back many times since I wrote the review.  Have gone to a couple of other spots for Ramen, but I have to say this place has the best!

20.description: Umai is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in Chicago. There are always plenty of Japanese dishes to choose from and the fish is always fresh. Furthermore, the vegetarian sushi options make it very easy to arrange dinners with friends who may not enjoy Japanese food otherwise.The best ramen I have had so far in Chicago, I have found at Umai. The soup base and noodle texture are on par with the Ippudo chain of restaurants, a personal favorite of mine when I visit the likes of Taipei and New York. The Nabeyaki Udon is also a delicious alternative during the winter time.The sushi and sashimi is always fresh. I enjoy anything from the spicy tuna, made with honey sriracha to the ama ebi, classically served with the shrimp heads.Umai is always a great place to stop in the South Loop and I always look forward to returning.

36.description: Kitchen closed at 9 45... This has happened a few times before, they are not very friendly if you come late for a drink either.

14.description: Ordered:    -Miso Ramen = Delicious   -Green Tea = On Point    -California Maki Roll = Good just a little too salty :/   -Lychee Sorbet = Good Overall I loved the food and you're given water free lol One star taken away because waitress wasn't the greatest, not very kind.

58.description: As many reviewers in the area, i wanted to love this place but there were many aspects lacking. The chairs were not comfortable. I felt like i was sitting at a sports bar based on the setup. Service was spotty. The busperson kept wanting to clear out our dishes that we were still working on. It took about 10 mins for the waitress to find the dessert menu for us. Took her another 15 minutes to come back and take our dessert order. When we got the bougatsa, it took another 20 mins to arrive. There should be some note on the menu or the waitress should have given the expectation that the bougatsa needs a longer time to prepare.About the food... the skirt steak was the only dish in my opinion done right and was good. Roasted califlower was drenched in oil. Bikini sandwich was just ok. 4 very small pieces of sandwich bits and rosemary was a little too overpowering. Potatas bravas is usually my favorite dish but it was not here. Potatoes were deep fried and oil soaked. Crunchy but it tasted like i was biting into oil cubes. The 3 spreads (hummus, baba ganouch, potato) were all too bland without much flavor. The dessert at the end was good but not so good that i would come back for more. The wine pour was just too gentle of a pour. My barely 4 ounce st francis cabernet was $12. If the food was great, i would be able to deal with the off par service and maybe the stingy wine pour. I would not care to return unless friends insist to.

56.description: The food had great flavors and was well cooked. Server was attentive and dishes were well staggered. Will return often.

29.description: Who doesn't love tapas and small plates? Okay, I guess a lot of people don't, mainly because they add up price wise really fast in order to make it a meal. And I get that, and Sociale isn't any different. But if you want to grab just a bit or two and a drink, this place I think is the perfect addition to the area. The decor is really nice, you feel like you are eating out on an adventure, the dimly lit restaurant space, the bar space or table areas, all of it pairs together so well and they have outdoor seating with the weather is nice too. Plus this place marked my introduction to pistachio butter! Yup, butter made out of pureed pistachios  that has to be one of the best things I have eaten in a long time! This was paired with perfectly seared scallops and I really and truly had difficulty sharing this dish with Matt J. We also got their house made burrata with their house made bread and the bread itself we thought could have been a little more flavorful and it seemed pretty dry too. But the cheese itself was quite tasty so with a better bread option I think that dish would have been much improved. But really that pistachio butter though!!! I need to now make pistachio butter all the time and eat it on everything because Sociale you changed my world with that small ingredient!

42.description: Had the pleasure of working along side Chef Mark years ago. Great guy, great restaurant. Needed it in South Loop. Why not 5 stars? I reserve that rating for Michelin spots haha!!

23.description: Unfortunately, we were not impressed with this place at all.  The ambience was nice, but too quiet. The service was good and the menu okay, but the food needs a lot of work. Nothing was seasoned.. Even the flatbread wasn't all that great.  The pork belly was cold.  The steak had no seasoning other than the toppings. I think this place has a lot of potential, but would recommend to wait for improvements to be made before visiting this place.

47.description: Sociale Chicago is a new tapas style restaurant that recently opened in Printers row.  I had high hopes for the place since it opened, and finally had the chance to visit.  I loved the ambiance of the restaurant, its modern design, mood lighting, and large windows make for a great date spot.  The service is similarly impeccable.  We were seated quickly, the servers were attentive, and the food came out quickly.  Unfortunately, the food left a little to be desired.  The pork belly pintxos was much too salty, it might just be my taste buds but some sweetness would benefit the dish immensely.  The patatas bravas were decent but nothing special.  The field greens salad was very pretty and tasted like a salad (exactly what you expect).  The brie and bacon jam flatbread sounded amazing on the menu, but just like the other food it was underwhelming.  The dessert was by far my favorite dish of the night.  All in all: the food sounds better on the menu than it tastes, but the prices are reasonable and if you live in the area this place is worth a visit, especially for drinks and dessert.  FYI: For two people we shared 4 dishes, dessert, and had one cocktail and one glass of wine.  The total came out to roughly $60.

8.description: Came here for a friend's birthday and it just so happen to open up recently.I love the concept of tapas for new restaurants. Shareable plates and not having to feel committed to one entree. If your entree sucks then you are just stuck with it. At least when you go with a group and get a bunch of tapas you have variety to choose from.Ordered a flat bread, scallops, feta burrata and the bone in rib eye.I would have to say that the best dish was the tomahawk rib eye! It was a tender aged piece of meat and a a hefty portion of food to share.  If you are a meat lover then you might want to consider just ordering the rib eye.... And not share it at all. Feta burrata is house made and came with bread to share.  If you're looking for a creamy piece of cheese to spread in bread, best thing ever!Definitely a restaurant that is worth checking out in this neighborhood!

31.description: Great service, wine list, atmosphere and last but not least, the food!!! This place is a must! Looking forward to coming back again soon.

34.description: This is a great new spot in the South Loop. The staff was very welcoming, attentive, and helpful with suggestions. I'm looking forward to another night here!Try the sangria! It was suggested to us, and it was delicious. We tried the white - it was almost like spiced wine with a zing of citrus. Very unique.

16.description: It could have been the company, the wine, the food but probably all of the above.  Regardless, Sociale is a truly great addition to the South loop.  I don't make my way over to the area all that often but will definitely be back now to dine at Sociale.  Our evening started with a chef's selection of sorts with all of our dishes perfectly paired with various vino.  The first of many tapas was a burrata like no other, it was probably one of the best burratas that I have ever had and I have tried it on nearly every menu I've seen it.  What made Sociales so good was the addition of feta cheese on the inside and topped with a duo of delicious sauces.  The only minor criticism I have is the bread it was served with could have been a bit crispier. After the Burrata, came the cod fritters, I was a little hesitant on these since I'm not huge cod fan but wow, they were super tasty and fresh.    Next, came the scallops, pan seared and served over a light and flavorful sauce and melt in your mouth tender. I think the biggest shocker for me was the grilled cauliflower, I hate cauliflower, repeat, I really hate cauliflower BUT somehow Sociale made me fall in love with it, at least there :), I'm not sure what kind of voodoo magic they did in the kitchen but whatever it was, keep it up because I have never eaten a vegetable that has tasted better. Lastly, some good old fashioned meat.   Being quite the carnivore, the steak chimichurri served with roasted potatoes was perfectly cooked and beyond flavorful, I almost forgot we also had some Papas Bravas so I definitely has my meat and potato fix for the evening.  Having a major sweet tooth was a bit of a problem seeing as how I ate so much deliciousness prior to dessert I barely had any room but that doesn't mean that I didn't get down on the amazingly rich and delectable chocolate panna cotta so gooood,  nice and balanced and not overwhelmingly sweet.  The rest of the group opted for the zeppolis aka "doughnuts" served with an awesome chocolate ganache.  Sociale really hit the mark on so many levels, service was fantastic food was delicious an overall atmosphere and vibe was great. I will be back!

13.description: I happen to be in town and was walking in the neighborhood, so I decided to stop by. The weather in Chicago is unusually warm, and it's a gorgeous day out. Sociale had the windows open and the bar looked so inviting. I was warmly greeted by several staff members as soon as I walked in. Everyone was very friendly. I ordered a cocktail and the Brie with Bacon Jam flatbread. OMG, it was amazing! I tried not to devour the whole thing, but my tummy wants what it wants. The bacon-onion jam paired perfectly with the brie and cured egg yolk on top. I'm going to convince the Hubs to join me for another meal before we head back to Atlanta. I need to enjoy this at least once more.

11.description: Came here after church with some friends and was delighted by the experience.  The wine display is nice and makes me want to come back in the evening! A small brunch menu that is fairly priced with portion sizes somewhere between tapas and a main course.  The flatbread was tasty, as was the panzarella salad...my fave of the afternoon. There were hardly any people in the place, but I think it was because we visited during a Bears game and while TVs are installed, they must not be set up yet.  Promises to be a great addition to Printers Row/the South Loop.

39.description: Good was was really good. Atmosphere was a little pretentious for the area. And way overpriced.  If you want want any chance to be full, order at least one flatbread.

37.description: Sociale is a really nice addition to the South Loop. Glad they got their liquor license because they have a very impressive wine list. I had a tempranillo that I really enjoyed. Our server, Stacy, said the chef is also a sommelier. The menu options are varied and there are several interesting choices. Great date place. I'll be back. It would be fun to have dinner at the bar some night, You can feel the owner cares. The decorating is impressive.

0.description: Came at 7:00 pm on Saturday. We were seated promptly by our hostess, followed by two glasses of water as we sat down for our Tapas style dinner. Potatas bravas, Brussel sprouts, skirt steak, and the lamb meatballs. Meatballs came out immediately- they were very tasty, but cold. Brussel sprouts were soft and crispy with a wonderfully distant, but distinct flavor. Skirt steak, again, was tasty, but cold. The Potatas bravas were amazing- Hot, flavorful, and crispy. The sauces on top and underneath were great. Two cold beers called for the Salmon Flat Bread..This was the stand out dish for the entire meal. The cured salmon was outstanding. With Bougatsa for dessert it was a complete meal. A thin, flaky pastry folded over a delicious, bright - lightly citrus flavored filling. Not always one for dessert, but it was a great cap to the whole experience. Everyone from the hostess, the chef, our waitor, to the owner, thanked us for joining them. Extremely friendly staff. I will come again.

38.description: My husband and I came here yesterday evening and sat at the bar.  We had heard great things about this new addition to our neighborhood and were very glad to try it. We indulged in several of their cocktails, which their cocktail menu has many creative options.  I first tried the Lisbon, and it was delicious.  It had a mix of bourbon, carpano antica, port, and bitters with grapes for garnishes.  The combination was smooth and subtly sweet.  I then opted for the Chicagoan, which contained rye, vermouth, grand marnier, and bitters with cherries for garnishes.  It was a delightful rendition of the Manhattan.  My husband chose the Snappy Mule.  Served in a copper cup, it combined vodka, snap liqueur, ginger beer, and a pleasant addition of mint.  He was very satisfied with his selection.We also tried their smoked salmon flatbread, which was divine.  They have a fire oven for their flatbreads and other dishes, which always adds extra flavor to your dish.  The salmon flatbread contained not only fresh smoked salmon but also a wonderful cream spread with chives and cucumbers.  The restaurant has a warm ambiance with both bar and table seating.  The staff was welcoming and friendly, prompt and attentive.  As other reviewers have mentioned, it can become pricey pretty quickly though with multiple tapas and cocktails.  Overall, I'd recommend this restaurant, and I look forward to coming back.

51.description: Checked out this new addition to South Loop with some friends for dinner.  While the waitstaff seemed a bit green, they were super nice and friendly.  We ordered a number of their small plates and a flat bread order to share among the three of us which enabled us to share a variety of selections off of their menu.  Everything we ordered was pretty good especially the pork belly pintxos and their grilled manouri cheese which were all cooked very nicely and were tasty to the palette.  I also really liked the grilled octopus, but could have done without the fennel.  I'm interested in trying some of their other selections next time.

27.description: Pretty decent tapas, great drinks, and good environment. Does get a little too loud during peak hours, but well worth the trip. We got five plates for two people and that was more than enough food. Favorite dish was the pork butts wrapped in bacon! Drinks were on the pricier side.

32.description: I'd like to go again and try more. Nothing absolutely blew me away, but everything was solid.Friday lunch, 2 of us:Pork Pinxtos - $7 - served as 2 bites, roughly 1" cubes of pork belly wrapped in bacon. I really liked the thick syrupy sauce that accompanied this- tangy and not too sweet. Not really possible to split each bite, so order 2+ for a group.Chicken Thigh- $8 - really liked the buttery white beans cassoulet this is served with. Chicken was decent, with a nice crisp skin, but could have used more seasoning. I recommend this tho.Walnut salad- $8 - pretty straight up- nothing special. Solid.Feta Burrate- $8 - it was good, served with some toast. Good starter for sure- nice big ball of soft cheese for the table.Chorizo flatbread- $10 - I like the crust/dough- the pizza still didn't have a ton of character though. So- seemed like quality ingredients, made with care- not trying to do too much, which is good from one perspective, but also no home runs in our limited encounter.We didn't have any drinks, so $54 total after tip.

54.description: What a delight to have another option for "grownup dining" in the South Loop/Printers Row neighborhood! With our large student population, our nearby choices are typically fast, casual, and inexpensive. Sociale adds something extra special to the mix. We went early on the chilly, rainy Halloween night, so getting a table was easy. Our server was very attentive, informative and made excellent suggestions. The small plates approach is our favorite way to eat and this menu did not disappoint; truly not a dud the entire evening. In reading other reviews about the spotty service, one answer may be servers who are new to the tapas style of serving. Our server mentioned that, although he's had several years of experience, this has been a learning curve for him. He also mentioned that Friday nights are the busiest. We will definitely go back - often.

48.description: Came here after church with some friends and was delighted by the experience.  The wine display is nice and makes me want to come back in the evening! A small brunch menu that is fairly priced with portion sizes somewhere between tapas and a main course.  The flatbread was tasty, as was the panzarella salad...my fave of the afternoon. There were hardly any people in the place, but I think it was because we visited during a Bears game and while TVs are installed, they must not be set up yet.  Promises to be a great addition to Printers Row/the South Loop.

44.description: Sociale is an amazing addition to Printers Row!  My fiance and I have been a few times for dinner and the food is always delicious. There is something for everyone with both small plates and full entrees.  Some of our favorites are the sumac crusted scallops, house made burrata, grilled bone-in ribeye (ginormous), and the manila clams with chorizo.  We also went last week for brunch and had equally yummy food---the sociale benedict and the bloody mary are both awesome!The best part of Sociale, however, is the service and atmosphere.  We are treated like family from the moment we walk in.  Chef Mark and Manager Mark are both so welcoming and always making great suggestions for what to try. They are passionate about what they do, and it definitely comes across in both the food and the service.We will definitely keep coming back!

24.description: Delicious!  Try the skirt steak, panzanekla, and chicken thigh. The beans they serve with the chicken are unbelievable!  This place is very cheffy but not in a weird way. Everything is just plain good.  Also have their version of a gin and tonic called a g and t. Yummy and potent. Plus our server was too awesome!

7.description: Delicious!  Try the skirt steak, panzanekla, and chicken thigh. The beans they serve with the chicken are unbelievable!  This place is very cheffy but not in a weird way. Everything is just plain good.  Also have their version of a gin and tonic called a g and t. Yummy and potent. Plus our server was too awesome!

49.description: Ordered a spread for take-out. Wasn't a bad dish in the bunch. The caramelized onion and brie flatbread from the wood oven had a great crust. The skirt steak came with some potatoes, so could have skipped the bravas.Looks like a nice atmosphere to eat in too...

40.description: Made reservations hours earlier and when my boyfriend and I arrived, the place was abuzz and we were immediately shown to our table, which was in a great spot. We ordered sangria rojo, delicious, and was told the specials. We got the grilled octopus (which I never had), Brie flatbread, porkbelly pintxos, and clams. I would order everything multiple times over in one sitting. Especially the octopus with grilled fennel and the Brie flatbread with bacon jam. Absolutely delicious and delightful! The porkbelly wrapped in bacon was hot out the kitchen and melted in my mouth with full of amazing flavor and magic. The staff was very attentive and friendly. I'm sure this place will be a hot spot for Spanish Mediterranean cuisine in the South Loop. Thank you for your service. We will be back.

53.description: I happen to be in town and was walking in the neighborhood, so I decided to stop by. The weather in Chicago is unusually warm, and it's a gorgeous day out. Sociale had the windows open and the bar looked so inviting. I was warmly greeted by several staff members as soon as I walked in. Everyone was very friendly. I ordered a cocktail and the Brie with Bacon Jam flatbread. OMG, it was amazing! I tried not to devour the whole thing, but my tummy wants what it wants. The bacon-onion jam paired perfectly with the brie and cured egg yolk on top. I'm going to convince the Hubs to join me for another meal before we head back to Atlanta. I need to enjoy this at least once more.

30.description: Such a cute place! They had a great draft IPA. I went there with two friends and we ordered: - smoked salmon flat bread - it was above average, but not exceptional - clams - the best clams I've ever had. I am definitely going back there for the clams - scallops - a little pricey ($12 for 2) but so delicious! They were well cooked and the pistachio butter was great with them. I will order that again next time I am there - beats salad - it was a pretty average beats salad - octopus - wasn't too impressed by it, but I am not a huge octopus fan to begin with - chicken with potatoes - that was good. My friend got it last time she was there and recommended to get it again - I don't remember what the desert was called, but there were 7 sweet balls with chocolate dip in the middle. The waitress recommended a different one, but we didn't listen. We will listen next time lol

46.description: whats good about em:-Superior Staff-Trendy Place-Some notable dishes: Chimichurri steak, field green saladwhats bad about em: -Valet was no where to be found, finally when the hostess was about to get a hold of him, he couldn't find his key to open his stand to give us a ticket. We were told we could just park in their lot for free for the inconvenience, only to be interrupted mid dinner that they found their keys and needed to take our car keys to use their parking lot for valet service, and then charged us the valet fee at the end. It was confusing & unprofessional, but the manager of the restaurant was very apologetic and comped our drinks which we werent expecting & was very kind. However, they should really find a new valet company..-Cod fritters have a weird texture. -Patata bravas has some nice crispy pieces but a majority was mush, maybe I am partial to how cafe iberico cooks theirs..?-Ordered a whole branzino which came out completely raw. At first the waiter tried to say they might serve it like that on purpose..... then took it back to the kitchen for them to cook through. The mashed potatoes they served with the fish were COLD, like actually cold. When they brought the fish back to the table it was this piled mess of fish and veggies. And the potatoes were still cold, with the exception of some areas being luke warm from them cooking the fish.We skipped out on dessert. The staff was great and decor to match, but we wont be back.

1.description: Decided to give Sociale a try for Friday night dinner. The atmosphere was casual and a little loud. Service was friendly. We started with cocktails, which were strong but not that great. I'm not sure why my G&T (made with gin, limoncello, St. Germain, and tonic) had a slice of cucumber in it. Didn't make much sense to muddle the citrus/elderflower flavor a with cucumber.The menu is tapas style so we ordered a few dishes at a time. Started with the brie with bacon jam flatbread, grilled octopus, and feta burrata. The flatbread was tasty but the dough beneath the toppings lacked any crispness and got soggy. The octopus was tough but paired well with the pickled fennel and grapefruit. I liked the feta burrata because the eggplant purée underneath added a nice sweetness to balance out the salty cheese. Then we had the lamb meatballs, patatas bravas, Brussels sprouts (from the specials menu) and the crisp chicken thigh. I can't say I really enjoyed any of these dishes. At $9 for two meatballs, I expect a more than an under seasoned meatball in a basic tomato sauce (I was really disappointed because I love lamb). The potatoes had great texture but the saffron aioli got lost in the dish and the salsa at the bottom could have been better. The Brussels sprouts were basic and something in the dish was really bitter - maybe the charred sprout leaves or onions...not sure. The chicken thigh had the crispy skin but the dish overall lacked freshness and felt quite heavy. We decided to give dessert a chance and ordered the flourless chocolate cake and the bougatsa. Both were just okay. I would have liked the chocolate cake more if it wasn't so hard to cut into. We had to use a knife and it was still hard to cut! It's more like a dense chocolate bar but the flavor was good if you like bittersweet chocolate. Overall, Sociale was really underwhelming. Each dish was almost good but definitely missed the mark. This is not a foodie's paradise, which is sad because we really need one in south loop! Maybe with some tweaking they could get there.

55.description: I HIGHLY recommend Sociale! The food was so tasty, and with it being tapas style we got to try a unique combination of food items. We had the lamb meatballs, the bacon and Brie flatbread, the Manchego cheese Dish and 2 desserts! And topped it all off with a pitcher of white sangria (I believe the seasonal flavor was ginger pear..so yummy).The food was great, but the service was even better. They were very attentive and knowledgable about the menu. The chef who created our dessert item even came out to our table to introduce himself, as well as the manager and our waiter. Seemed like everyone there was passionate about high quality food and high quality service- as any great restaurant should be.

9.description: Who doesn't love tapas and small plates? Okay, I guess a lot of people don't, mainly because they add up price wise really fast in order to make it a meal. And I get that, and Sociale isn't any different. But if you want to grab just a bit or two and a drink, this place I think is the perfect addition to the area. The decor is really nice, you feel like you are eating out on an adventure, the dimly lit restaurant space, the bar space or table areas, all of it pairs together so well and they have outdoor seating with the weather is nice too. Plus this place marked my introduction to pistachio butter! Yup, butter made out of pureed pistachios  that has to be one of the best things I have eaten in a long time! This was paired with perfectly seared scallops and I really and truly had difficulty sharing this dish with Matt J. We also got their house made burrata with their house made bread and the bread itself we thought could have been a little more flavorful and it seemed pretty dry too. But the cheese itself was quite tasty so with a better bread option I think that dish would have been much improved. But really that pistachio butter though!!! I need to now make pistachio butter all the time and eat it on everything because Sociale you changed my world with that small ingredient!

26.description: My sister and I went here for an early dinner on a Monday. The waitress Heather gave us great suggestions and we ended up ordering the pork belly, verdure flatbread, homemade burrata, and the scallops. Everything was so fresh and amazing. The scallops were so good that we ordered them twice. The dessert- the phyllo dough- was one of the best desserts I've ever had. The wine selection was great along with the atmosphere. The sous chef came out to explain some of the dishes, which really added to the experience. Everyone should make it to this spot- absolutely amazing!

25.description: I have passed Sociale a few times and wanted to go in. A friend and I decided to drop in for a snack and a drink. Somehow that turned into steak and several rounds of drinks. We shared the bone-in rib eye steak. It was delicious like we were at one of the fancy downtown steak houses.
